    • dexamethasone phosphate 24 mg (6 mg, 12 hourly, 4 doses) versus betamethasone phosphate, acetate/phosphate or dipropionate 24 mg (12 mg, 24 hourly, 2 doses) (total 517 women and 577 infants; Elimian 2007; Rotmensch 1999; Subtil 2003; Urban 2005);

    • dexamethasone (unspecified) 24 mg (12 mg, 12 hourly, 2 doses) and betamethasone 24 mg (unspecified; or betamethasone acetate/phosphate) (12 mg, 12 hourly, 2 doses) (total 91 women and 91 infants; Magee 1997; Mushkat 2001);

    • dexamethasone phosphate 16 mg (4 mg, 12 hourly, 4 doses) and betamethasone phosphate or acetate/phosphate 24 mg (6 mg, 12 hourly, 4 doses) (82 women and 82 infants; Senat 1998);

    • dexamethasone phosphate 24 mg (12 mg, 12 hourly, 2 doses) and betamethasone acetate/phosphate 24 mg (12 mg, 24 hourly, 2 doses) (60 women and 60 infants; Mulder 1997);

    • dexamethasone phosphate 24 mg (12 mg, 24 hourly, 2 doses) versus betamethasone acetate/phosphate 22.8 mg (11.4 mg, 24 hourly, 2 doses) (1346 women and 1509 infants; Crowther 2019).

    Comparisons of different regimens and preparations of dexamethasone or betamethasone (comparisons 2 to 4)

    One trial compared different dexamethasone regimens: oral dexamethasone phosphate 32 mg (8 mg, 12 hourly, 4 doses) versus intramuscular dexamethasone phosphate 24 mg (6 mg, 12 hourly, 4 doses) (170 women and 183 infants; Egerman 1998).

    The other two trials compared different preparations or regimens (or both) of betamethasone. One three‐arm trial compared two forms of betamethasone (acetate plus phosphate versus phosphate alone) (69 women and 69 infants; Subtil 2003). This trial also included a third group who received dexamethasone, which we have included in the comparison of dexamethasone versus betamethasone. The other trial compared dosing intervals of betamethasone acetate plus phosphate (12 mg, 24 hourly, 2 doses versus 12 mg, 12 hourly, 2 doses) (228 women and 260 infants) (Khandelwal 2012). 

    Repeat courses

    Five trials comparing dexamethasone versus betamethasone allowed repeat weekly courses of the allocated corticosteroid (Crowther 2019; Egerman 1998; Magee 1997; Mushkat 2001; Senat 1998) (see Table 1).

    Primary outcomes in included studies

    The primary outcomes varied between trials. The primary outcomes of six trials focused on neonatal outcomes including RDS, IVH and death (Crowther 2019; Egerman 1998; Elimian 2007; Khandelwal 2012; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003), and also child outcomes of neurodisability at 18 months (Subtil 2003) or 24 months (Crowther 2019). The other five trials concentrated on biophysical parameters of the fetus (Magee 1997; Mulder 1997; Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999; Urban 2005).

    Excluded studies

    We excluded 10 trials (see Characteristics of excluded studies table):

    • three compared L‐carnitine plus corticosteroid versus corticosteroid to assess the effect of L‐carnitine (Kurz 1993; Salzer 1982; Vytiska‐Binstorfer 1985);

    • one compared thyroxine plus corticosteroid versus corticosteroid to assess the effects of thyroxine (Romaguera 1997);

    • one compared vitamin K plus corticosteroid versus corticosteroid, vitamin K and no treatment to assess the effects of vitamin K (Liu 2006);

    • one was a cross‐over trial (Egerman 1997);

    • one compared corticosteroids (either dexamethasone or betamethasone) versus placebo (Shanks 2010);

    • one where the study population did not meet our inclusion criteria, as it included women up to 38 weeks' gestation (Sukarna 2021);

    • two trials were not randomised (IRCT2014090912789N6; Whitt 1976).

    Studies awaiting classification

    Nine studies are awaiting classification (see Characteristics of studies awaiting classification table).

    Ongoing studies

    Seven studies are ongoing (see Characteristics of ongoing studies table).

    Risk of bias in included studies

    While one new study was at overall low risk of bias (Crowther 2019), overall, the other trials were at moderate risk of bias (see Figure 3 and Figure 4).

    • Open in figure viewer
    Figure 3

    Risk of bias graph: review authors' judgements about each risk of bias item presented as percentages across all included studies.

    • Open in figure viewer
    Figure 4

    Risk of bias summary: review authors' judgements about each risk of bias item for each included study.

    For further details on the risk of bias in individual studies, see the risk of bias table within the Characteristics of included studies table.

    Allocation

    Methods of sequence generation and allocation concealment were both adequate in five trials (low risk; Crowther 2019; Elimian 2007; Khandelwal 2012; Magee 1997; Urban 2005).

    In four further trials, while methods of random sequence generation were adequate (low risk), methods to conceal allocation were unclear (Egerman 1998; Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003). One trial was at unclear risk of selection bias, with methods of sequence generation and allocation concealment being unclear (Mulder 1997).

    In one trial, while the method of sequence generation was at low risk of bias, participants were allocated alternately (based on odd/even computer‐generated number), so allocation concealment was at high risk of bias (Mushkat 2001).

    Blinding

    Four trials were at a low risk of performance bias, with blinding of women and personnel (Crowther 2019; Elimian 2007; Magee 1997; Mushkat 2001). For one trial, the risk of performance bias was unclear, as blinding of women was not detailed (Rotmensch 1999). The remaining six trials were at a high risk of performance bias, with no blinding of women and study personnel (or blinding considered unfeasible) (Egerman 1998; Khandelwal 2012; Mulder 1997; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003; Urban 2005).

    Four trials were at a low risk of detection bias, with blinding of outcome assessment (Crowther 2019; Elimian 2007; Khandelwal 2012; Magee 1997). One trial was at high risk of detection bias, with no blinding of outcome assessors (Subtil 2003). The remaining six trials were at unclear risk of detection bias (Egerman 1998;  Mulder 1997; Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Urban 2005).

    Incomplete outcome data

    Two trials were at low risk of attrition bias (Egerman 1998; Senat 1998). 

    While short‐term loss to follow‐up was minimal and well‐documented in Crowther 2019, there were losses of 20% to 25% in both groups for longer‐term outcomes, and, therefore, we assessed this trial at unclear risk of attrition bias overall. 

    Two trials did not document losses to follow‐up and were at unclear risk of attrition bias (Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999). Mulder 1997 reported a 17% loss to follow‐up (6/30 from the dexamethasone group and 4/30 from the betamethasone group), and Elimian 2007 assessed less than 60% of all infants for IVH and PVL. Urban 2005 did not mention exclusions or attrition; however, all results were reported as a mean, and so it was not possible to know whether there were losses. In Magee 1997 and Subtil 2003, losses were greater than 50% at the end of follow‐up for some of the biophysical parameters.

    Khandelwal 2012 was at high risk of attrition bias. In addition to documented losses to follow‐up for whom some outcomes are in fact reported, the report states that only babies in whom clinical evaluation was deemed relevant were assessed for some outcomes (e.g. IVH, ROP, CLD); however, it was unclear whether all babies were accounted for given inconsistent variation in denominators for these outcomes.

    Selective reporting

    There was no obvious risk of selective reporting in two trials (low risk; Crowther 2019; Subtil 2003).

    While two trials prespecified their outcomes in the manuscript methods, the risk of reporting bias was unclear, with outcome data reported incompletely for some clinical outcomes (e.g. "gestational age, birthweight and Apgar score at five minutes did not differ between the two groups") (Egerman 1998; Mushkat 2001), or one trial reported additional outcomes (Elimian 2007).

    One trial reported all prespecified outcomes from the methods and trial registration; however, the authors registered the trial during recruitment and, therefore, we assessed risk of reporting bias as unclear (Khandelwal 2012).

    The remaining five trials reported some important clinical outcomes; however, with no access to a trial protocol it was difficult to confidently assess selective reporting; therefore, we judged these studies at unclear risk of reporting bias (Magee 1997; Mulder 1997; Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Urban 2005).

    Other potential sources of bias

    For nine trials, groups were comparable at baseline and there were no other obvious sources of bias identified (Crowther 2019; Egerman 1998; Elimian 2007; Magee 1997; Mulder 1997; Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999; Subtil 2003; Urban 2005). 

    Two trials were at unclear risk of other bias; Khandelwal 2012 due to some baseline imbalances between groups regarding age and ethnicity, and Senat 1998 because in the case of multiple pregnancy, one fetus only was randomly selected for analysis.

    Effects of interventions

    See: Summary of findings 1 Dexamethasone compared to betamethasone – maternal outcomes; Summary of findings 2 Dexamethasone compared to betamethasone – fetal/neonatal outcomes; Summary of findings 3 Dexamethasone compared to betamethasone – child outcomes; Summary of findings 4 Dexamethasone: oral compared to intramuscular – fetal/neonatal outcomes; Summary of findings 5 Betamethasone acetate plus phosphate compared to betamethasone phosphate – fetal/neonatal outcomes; Summary of findings 6 Betamethasone 12‐hourly compared to 24‐hourly dosing – fetal/neonatal outcomes

    We included 11 trials involving 2494 women and 2762 babies.

    The results are presented by type of corticosteroid or method of administration compared:

    • dexamethasone versus betamethasone (Crowther 2019; Elimian 2007; Magee 1997; Mulder 1997; Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003; Urban 2005);

    • oral versus intramuscular dexamethasone (Egerman 1998);

    • betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate (Subtil 2003);

    • betamethasone 12‐hourly doses versus betamethasone 24‐hourly doses (Khandelwal 2012).

    1. Dexamethasone versus betamethasone

    Nine trials including 2096 women and 2319 infants compared dexamethasone versus betamethasone (Crowther 2019; Elimian 2007; Magee 1997; Mulder 1997; Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003; Urban 2005).

    Primary outcomes
    Women

    Chorioamnionitis

    Although the rate of chorioamnionitis was lower with dexamethasone when compared with betamethasone, given the wide 95% CIs crossed the line of no effect, there was no conclusive evidence of difference (RR 0.71, 95% CI 0.48 to 1.06; 1 trial, 1346 women; anticipated absolute effects (AAE): 83 events per 1000 women with betamethasone, 24 fewer per 1000 women with dexamethasone, 95% CI 43 fewer to 5 more; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.1; summary of findings Table 1).

    Unreported outcomes

    No studies reported maternal death or puerperal sepsis.

    Fetus/neonate

    Any known death after randomisation

    When combining the evidence on any known death after randomisation, there is probably no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone; however, given the wide 95% CIs, the evidence is not conclusive (RR 1.03, 95% CI 0.66 to 1.63; 5 trials, 2105 infants; AAE 32 per 1000 infants with betamethasone, 1 more per 1000 infants with dexamethasone (95% CI 11 fewer to 20 more); moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.2; summary of findings Table 2).

    Respiratory distress syndrome

    There is little or no difference in the risk of RDS between dexamethasone and betamethasone (RR 1.06, 95% CI 0.91 to 1.22; 5 trials, 2105 infants; high‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.3; summary of findings Table 2).

    Intraventricular haemorrhage

    There was substantial statistical heterogeneity in the effect estimate for IVH (average risk ratio (aRR) 0.71, 95% CI 0.28 to 1.81; 4 trials, 1902 infants; AAE 52 per 100 infants with betamethasone, 15 fewer with dexamethasone (38 fewer to 42 more); low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.4; summary of findings Table 2; Tau² = 0.38; Chi² = 5.20, degrees of freedom (df) = 2 (P = 0.07); I² = 62%). There were too few trials contributing data to investigate this heterogeneity with subgroup analyses as planned. However, one trial reported a result that differed substantially from the other studies, suggesting a substantial decrease in risk with dexamethasone (Elimian 2007). We noted that this trial did not report on IVH for all infants (IVH reported for 100/181 infants in dexamethasone group and 105/178 infants in betamethasone group), and sensitivity analysis removing this study eliminated the statistical heterogeneity and suggests that there may be little or no difference between drugs for this outcome (RR 1.06, 95% CI 0.66 to 1.68; I² = 0). The GRADE assessment (low) reflects our lack of confidence in the pooled effect estimate, as well as the wide 95% CIs. 

    Child

    Death after hospital discharge

    One trial reported death after hospital discharge, up to two years adjusted age (Crowther 2019). There were few events in each group, and the effect estimate had wide 95% CIs, so  we are uncertain whether the choice of dexamethasone versus betamethasone makes a difference to the risk of this outcome (RR 0.65, 95% CI 0.11 to 3.89; 1 trial, 1509 infants; Analysis 1.5).

    Neurodevelopmental disability at follow‐up

    Two trials followed up children into childhood, however only one of them attempted to follow up all surviving infants (Crowther 2019). The results suggest that there is probably little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk of neurodevelopmental disability at follow‐up (RR 1.02, 95% CI 0.85 to 1.22; 2 trials, 1151 infants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.6; summary of findings Table 3). Crowther 2019 followed up children to two years' adjusted age (with balanced loss to follow‐up 22% with dexamethasone versus 26% with betamethasone), and children were considered to have a neurodevelopmental disability if they had cerebral palsy, were blind or deaf, or showed developmental delay (defined as a Bayley Infant and Toddler Development Scale, version 3 (BSID‐III) score in any of the cognitive, language and motor domains of greater than one standard deviation below the mean). Subtil 2003  followed up a subgroup of 12 children (eight in dexamethasone group versus four in betamethasone group) to 18 months (adjustment not mentioned), all of whom had been admitted to NICU as babies, and contributed only 0.4% to the weight of the pooled effect estimate. 

    Child as an adult

    The longest that any of the included trials followed up children was to two years of age (adjusted for prematurity), therefore, no studies reported primary outcomes for the child as an adult (death or neurodevelopmental disability at follow‐up).

    Secondary outcomes
    Women

    Fever after trial entry requiring the use of antibiotics

    For the mother, there is probably  little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk of postnatal fever requiring the use of antibiotics (RR 0.96, 95% CI 0.76 to 1.23; 1 trial, 1346 women; Analysis 1.7).

    Adverse effects of therapy

    The rate of maternal adverse effects of therapy was lower with dexamethasone; however, there was no conclusive evidence of a difference between interventions given the 95% CIs (RR 0.63, 95% CI 0.35 to 1.13; 2 trials, 1705 women; AAE 33 events per 1000 women with betamethasone, 12 fewer per 1000 women with dexamethasone (95% CI 22 fewer to 4 more); moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.8; summary of findings Table 1).

    Unreported outcomes

    No studies reported intrapartum fever requiring the use of antibiotics, postnatal fever requiring the use of antibiotics, admission to intensive care unit, glucose intolerance or hypertension.

    Fetus/neonate

    Fetal death

    There may be little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk of fetal death (RR 1.19, 95% CI 0.50 to 2.87; 1 trial, 1509 infants; Analysis 1.9).

    Neonatal death

    There may be little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk of neonatal death (RR 1.02, 95% CI 0.58 to 1.80; 5 trials, 2105 infants; Analysis 1.10). One neonate died four days after birth (Mulder 1997), one neonate with severe intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) died one day after caesarean section at 27 weeks' gestation (Subtil 2003), and in the other trials contributing data, there was no further information about timing. 

    Apgar score less than 7 at five minutes

    Only one small study reported Apgar score less than 7 at five minutes, and we are uncertain whether there is a difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone given the low number of babies, few events and very wide 95% CIs (RR 0.54, 95% CI 0.05 to  5.60; 1 trial, 50 infants; Analysis 1.11).

    Birthweight

    The choice of corticosteroid may make no difference to mean birthweight (MD 0.03 kg, 95% CI –0.05 to 0.11; 5 trials, 2066 infants; Analysis 1.12).

    Low birthweight

    The choice of corticosteroid may make no difference to whether the baby is at risk of being of low birthweight (RR 0.89, 95% CI 0.65 to 1.24; 1 trial, 105 infants; Analysis 1.13).

    Mean length at birth

    There may be little difference in the mean length at birth between groups (MD 0.10 cm, 95% CI –0.47 to 0.67; 1 trial, 1489 infants; Analysis 1.14).

    Mean head circumference at birth

    There may be little difference in the mean head circumference at birth between groups (MD 0.20 cm, 95% CI –0.18 to 0.58; 1 trial, 1489 infants; Analysis 1.15). 

    Admission to neonatal intensive care

    There was substantial statistical heterogeneity in the effect estimate for admission to NICU (aRR 1.75, 95% CI 0.49 to 6.25; 2 trials, 1614 infants; Analysis 1.16; Tau² = 0.71; Chi² = 5.18, df = 1 (P = 0.02); I² = 81%). Only two studies contributed data, with one small study reporting few events but twice as many in the smaller dexamethasone group (8/36 in the dexamethasone group versus 4/69 in the betamethasone group) (Subtil 2003). It was not possible to investigate this heterogeneity with subgroup analyses given that only two trials contributed data. It is possible that differences in the reasons for preterm birth, or other clinical factors, contributed to this heterogeneity. Sensitivity analysis limited to Crowther 2019, a large multicentre study free of significant risk of bias concerns, gave an effect estimate RR of 1.02 (95% CI 0.89 to 1.17), suggesting that the choice of drug may make little or no difference to this outcome. 

    Need for mechanical ventilation

    There is probably little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the need for mechanical ventilation (RR 0.94, 95% CI 0.74 to 1.19; 1 trial, 1509 infants; Analysis 1.17).

    Mean duration of mechanical ventilation

    There is probably little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the mean duration of mechanical ventilation (MD –0.38 days, 95% CI –1.11 to 0.35; 1 trial, 1509 infants; Analysis 1.18).

    Severity of respiratory distress syndrome

    There is probably no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for the risk of moderate/severe RDS (RR 1.06, 95% CI 0.80 to 1.39; 1 trial, 1509 infants; Analysis 1.19).

    Chronic lung disease

    There is probably no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for the risk of chronic lung disease (RR 0.92, 95% CI 0.64 to 1.34; 1 trial, 1509 infants; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.20; summary of findings Table 2).

    Bronchopulmonary dysplasia

    There was substantial statistical heterogeneity in the analyses for bronchopulmonary dysplasia (aRR 2.50, 95% CI 0.10 to 61.34; 2 trials, 464 infants; Analysis 1.21); there was no clear explanation for the heterogeneity (Tau² = 4.40; Chi² = 4.89, df = 1 (P = 0.03); I² = 80%). Elimian 2007 reported 18/178 events in the dexamethasone group versus 27/181 events in the betamethasone group, while Subtil 2003 reported 4/36 events in the dexamethasone group versus 0/69 events in the betamethasone group; for some other outcomes (e.g. admission to NICU; Analysis 1.16), Subtil 2003 differed from other trials in the high number of negative events for babies in the dexamethasone group. It is possible that limitations in the study design (risk of bias), differences in reasons for preterm birth or other clinical factors might explain this difference.

    Severe intraventricular haemorrhage

    There were no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone for the risk of severe IVH (RR 0.40, 95% CI 0.14 to 1.13; 4 trials, 1901 infants; Analysis 1.22).

    Periventricular leukomalacia

    There were no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone for the risk of periventricular leukomalacia (RR 0.64, 95% CI 0.18 to 2.25; 4 trials, 1901 infants; Analysis 1.23).

    Systemic infection in first 48 hours of life (neonatal sepsis)

    There were no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone for the risk of neonatal sepsis (RR 1.14, 95% CI 0.60 to 2.17; 1 trial, 359 infants; Analysis 1.24).

    Necrotising enterocolitis

    There were no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone for the risk of necrotising enterocolitis (RR 5.08, 95% CI 0.25 to 105.15; 2 studies, 441 infants; low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.26).

    Retinopathy of prematurity

    There was substantial statistical heterogeneity in the analysis for retinopathy of prematurity (aRR 0.32, 95% CI 0.02 to 5.50; 2 trials, 1868 infants; Analysis 1.27; Tau² = 3.34; Chi² = 4.07, df = 1 (P = 0.04); I² = 75%). The results from the two studies reporting this outcome differed considerably (Crowther 2019 reported 0/763 events in the dexamethasone group versus 8/746 events in the betamethasone group; Elimian 2007 reported 26/178 events in the dexamethasone group versus 28/181 events in the betamethasone group), and we are not confident that the point estimate reflects the true difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone.

    Patent ductus arteriosus

    There were no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone for the risk of patent ductus arteriosus (RR 1.20, 95% CI 0.82 to 1.76; 2 trials, 1868 infants; Analysis 1.28).

    Biophysical parameters

    Six trials reported a range of biophysical parameters for a small numbers of babies (Crowther 2019; Magee 1997; Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003).

    In five trials there were some differences in biophysical parameters relating to fetal heart rate, fetal movements and fetal breathing (Magee 1997; Mushkat 2001; Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003):

    • the dexamethasone group had a lower fetal heart rate than the betamethasone group at day two in Rotmensch 1999 (MD –4.20 beats per minute, 95% CI –7.17 to –1.23; 1 trial, 46 infants; Analysis 1.29) and in Senat 1998 (Analysis 1.30), but not in Magee 1997;

    • the dexamethasone group had a higher level of fetal movements detected via ultrasound than the betamethasone group (MD 7.0 movements per hour, 95% CI 2.15 to 11.85; 1 trial, 33 infants; Mushkat 2001; Analysis 1.34);

    • at day two, the dexamethasone group had a higher breathing times than the betamethasone group (MD 32.00 seconds in 30 minutes, 95% CI 4.37 to 59.63; 1 trial, 46 infants; Rotmensch 1999; Analysis 1.37).

    However, Crowther 2019 found no differences between groups for any biophysical measures. Crowther 2019 reported on a small substudy involving 43/1346 women (47/1509 fetuses) from two study centres, for whom the clinical team felt delaying corticosteroids for pretreatment ultrasound would not compromise clinical care, there was no suspicion of abnormal fetal cardiac morphology and who were not taking medication with potential major fetal cardiovascular effect. This substudy reported on short‐term ultrasound and cardiotocography (CTG) effects of dexamethasone versus betamethasone, up to seven to 10 days after administration. The authors concluded that there was no evidence of a difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for fetal or maternal Doppler studies, biophysical profile or CTG. 

    The other five trials also found no clear differences between betamethasone and dexamethasone for other biophysical parameters including:

    • accelerations per hour (MD 2.80, 95% CI –0.15 to 5.75; 1 trial, 46 infants; Rotmensch 1999; Analysis 1.31);

    • fetal movements in 30 minutes (MD 2.30, 95% CI –0.74 to 5.34; 1 trial, 46 infants; Rotmensch 1999; Analysis 1.32);

    • fetal movement via maternal perception (MD 3.00 movements per hour, 95% CI –3.20 to 9.20; 1 trial, 33 infants; Mushkat 2001; Analysis 1.33); and

    • fetal breathing movements per hour (MD 0, 95% CI –2.05 to 2.05; 1 trial, 33 infants; Mushkat 2001; Analysis 1.36).

    Subtil 2003 measured a range of fetal heart rate indicators but only reported them in graphical form; the trial authors reported that none of the indicators showed significant differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone. 

    Unreported outcomes

    No studies reported the interval between trial entry, birth, mean skin fold thickness at birth, small‐for‐gestational age, mean placental weight, neonatal blood pressure, need for inotropic support (days), air leak syndrome, need for oxygen supplementation, duration of oxygen supplementation (days), surfactant use, proven infection while in the NICU or HPA axis function.

    Child

    For all of the childhood outcomes reported below, the effect estimates are based on data from one study, which followed up children at two years of age (adjusted for prematurity) (Crowther 2019). In this trial, there was loss to follow‐up of 20% to 25% in both groups for these longer‐term outcomes. 

    Crowther 2019 reporting longer‐term secondary outcomes for the child measured motor developmental delay and intellectual impairment outcomes using the BSID‐III.

    Mean weight

    There may be little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for mean weight at two years adjusted age (MD 0 kg, 95% CI –0.23 to 0.23; 1 trial, 1208 children; Analysis 1.38).

    Mean length

    There may be little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for mean height at two years' adjusted age (MD 0.20 cm, 95% CI –0.39 to 0.79; 1 trial, 1187 children; Analysis 1.39).

    Mean head circumference

    There may be little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for mean head circumference at two years' adjusted age (MD 0.10 cm, 95% CI –0.14 to 0.34; 1 trial, 1188 children; Analysis 1.40).

    Mean blood pressure

    There may be little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for mean systolic blood pressure (MD –0.60 mmHg, 95% CI –2.23 to 1.03; 1 trial, 724 children; Analysis 1.41); or mean diastolic blood pressure (MD –0.10 mmHg, 95% CI –1.67 to 1.47; 1 trial, 703 children; Analysis 1.42).

    Visual impairment

    We found no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk at two years' adjusted age of visual impairment (RR 0.33, 95% CI 0.01 to 8.15; 1 trial, 1227 children; AAE 2 per 1000 children with betamethasone versus 1 per 1000 children with dexamethasone, 95% CI 0 to 13 per 1000; low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.43; summary of findings Table 3).

    Hearing impairment

    We found no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk at two years' adjusted age of hearing impairment (RR 1.16, 95% CI 0.63 to 2.16; 1 trial, 1227 children; AAE 29 per 100 children with betamethasone, 5 more per 1000 children with dexamethasone, 95% CI 11 fewer to 34 more; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.44; summary of findings Table 3).

    Developmental delay (mild, moderate or severe)

    We found no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone in motor developmental delay (mild, moderate or severe: defined as developmental quotient less than –1 standard deviations below population mean) (RR 0.89, 95% CI 0.66 to 1.20; 1 trial, 1166 children; AAE 135 per 1000 children with betamethasone, 15 fewer per 1000 with dexamethasone, 95% CI 46 fewer to 27 more; moderate‐certainty evidence; Analysis 1.45; summary of findings Table 3).

    Developmental delay (moderate or severe)

    We found no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone in motor developmental delay (moderate or severe: defined as developmental quotient less than –2 standard deviations below population mean) (RR 0.84, 95% CI 0.45 to 1.56; 1 trial, 1166 children; Analysis 1.46);

    Intellectual impairment (moderate or severe)

    We found no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone in intellectual impairment: cognitive or language developmental delay (moderate or severe: defined as developmental quotient less than –2 standard deviations below population mean) (RR 1.23, 95% CI 0.80 to 1.90; 1 trial, 1161 children; Analysis 1.47).

    Intellectual impairment (mild, moderate or severe)

    We found no clear differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone in intellectual impairment: cognitive or language developmental delay (mild, moderate or severe: defined as developmental quotient less than –1 standard deviations below population mean) (RR 0.97, 95% CI 0.79 to 1.20; 1 trial, 1161 children; moderate‐certainty evidence; AAE 234 per 1000 children with betamethasone, 7 fewer per 1000 with dexamethasone, 95% CI 49 fewer to 47 more; Analysis 1.48; summary of findings Table 3).

    Cerebral palsy

    For cerebral palsy, low‐certainty evidence suggested a result that was compatible with both no difference between the two drugs, and with an important increase in risk with dexamethasone (RR 2.50, 95% CI 0.97 to 6.39; 1 trial, 1223 children; AAE 10 per 1000 with betamethasone, 15 more per 1000 children with dexamethasone (95% CI 0 fewer to 53 more); Analysis 1.49; summary of findings Table 3). This result was downgraded for imprecision and risk of attrition bias (due to loss to follow‐up of about 80% in both groups).

    Behavioural/learning difficulties

    In terms of other outcomes related to behavioural/learning difficulties, Crowther 2019 compared educational achievement using mean BSID‐III scores between groups for three domains (cognitive, language and motor). There was little or no difference between children whose mothers had received dexamethasone versus betamethasone for any of the three domains:

    • educational achievement (cognitive score) (MD 0.50, 95% CI –1.28 to 2.28; 1 trial, 1199 children; Analysis 1.50);

    • educational achievement (language score) (MD 0.30, 95% CI –1.81 to 2.41; 1 trial, 1199 children; Analysis 1.51); and

    • educational achievement (motor score) (MD 0.10, 95% CI –1.75 to 1.95; 1 trial, 1199 children; Analysis 1.52).

    A psychometrist performed these BSID‐III assessments. The trial collected additional follow‐up information directly from caregivers using the Child Behaviour Checklist (CBCL), and there was also little or no difference  in the total mean score between groups (MD –0.40, 95% CI –2.68 to 1.88; 1 trial, 1253 children; Analysis 1.53). 

    Unreported outcomes

    The study did not report mean skin fold thickness, abnormal lung function, glucose intolerance, HPA axis function, dyslipidaemia or any neurodisability.

    Child as an adult

    No studies reported secondary outcomes for children as adults.

    Health services

    Mean length of antenatal hospitalisation for women (days)

    For the mother, the choice of drug made little or no difference to the mean length of postnatal hospitalisation (MD –0.10 days, 95% CI –0.33 to 0.13; 1 trial, 1346 women; Analysis 1.54).

    Mean length of postnatal hospitalisation for women (days)

    No studies reported mean length of postnatal hospitalisation for women.

    Mean length of neonatal hospitalisation (days)

    For the baby, it is possible that the mean length of neonatal hospitalisation may be slightly lower with dexamethasone; however, the 95% CIs were also compatible with no difference (MD –1.50 days, 95% CI  –3.61 to 0.61; 1 trial, 1489 infants; Analysis 1.55). 

    2. Dexamethasone (oral versus intramuscular injection)

    One trial compared oral versus intramuscular dexamethasone. It recruited 170 women, with 165 women and 183 infants analysed (Egerman 1998). This trial was stopped early at 39% enrolment after a blinded review of available outcomes, due to concerns that oral dexamethasone was associated with a higher risk of infant sepsis and IVH in babies born before 34 weeks' gestation.

    Primary outcomes
    Women

    The study reported no primary outcomes for women.

    Fetus/neonate

    We assessed the effect estimates for all primary outcomes for the baby to be very low certainty, due to concerns about risk of bias (unclear concealment of allocation and likely lack of blinding of participants or personnel) and imprecision (small single study, few events, and wide 95% CIs).

    Any known death after randomisation

    We are unsure whether there are any true differences between oral and intramuscular dexamethasone in the risk of any known death after randomisation (all deaths reported by this study were neonatal, and babies were not followed up longer term; RR 1.48, 95% CI 0.45 to 4.90; 1 trial, 183 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 2.1; summary of findings Table 4).

    Respiratory distress syndrome

    We are unsure whether there are any true differences between oral and intramuscular dexamethasone in the risk of RDS (RR 1.15, 95% CI 0.75 to 1.77; 1 trial, 183 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 2.2; summary of findings Table 4).

    Intraventricular haemorrhage

    We are unsure whether there are any true differences between oral and intramuscular dexamethasone in the risk of IVH (RR 4.24, 95% CI 0.96 to 18.83; 1 trial, 183 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 2.3; summary of findings Table 4). All instances of IVH (10 in the oral group and two in the intramuscular group) occurred in babies born before 34 weeks' gestation.

    Child

    Infants were not followed up into childhood or beyond. No studies reported primary outcomes for children.

    Child as an adult

    No study reported primary outcomes for children as adults.

    Secondary outcomes 
    Women

    No studies reported secondary outcomes for women.

    Fetus/neonate

    Birthweight

    Due to concerns about risk of bias and imprecision, we are uncertain of the true effects of oral versus intramuscular dexamethasone for birthweight (MD 0.05 kg, 95% CI –0.17 to 0.27; 1 trial, 183 infants; Analysis 2.4).

    Neonatal sepsis

    It is possible that treatment with oral dexamethasone may increase neonatal sepsis when compared with intramuscular dexamethasone; however, the evidence is very uncertain (RR 8.48, 95% CI 1.11 to 64.93; 1 trial, 183 infants; Analysis 2.5). All neonatal sepsis cases occurred in babies born before 34 weeks' gestation.

    Necrotising enterocolitis

    We are uncertain of the true effects of oral versus intramuscular dexamethasone for necrotising enterocolitis (RR 5.09, 95% CI 0.63 to 41.45; 1 trial, 183 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 2.6; summary of findings Table 4).

    Unreported outcomes

    The study did not report fetal death, neonatal death (up to 28 days after birth), Apgar score less than 7 at five minutes, interval between trial entry and birth, low birthweight, mean length at birth, mean head circumference at birth, mean skin fold thickness at birth, small‐for‐gestational age, mean placental weight, neonatal blood pressure, admission to NICU, need for inotropic support (days), need for mechanical ventilation/continuous positive airways pressure, mean duration of mechanical ventilation/continuous positive airways pressure (days), air leak syndrome, need for oxygen supplementation, duration of oxygen supplementation (days), surfactant use, severity of RDS, chronic lung disease, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, severe IVH, periventricular leukomalacia, proven infection while in the NICU, retinopathy of prematurity, patent ductus arteriosus, HPA axis function or biophysical parameters.

    Child

    No studies reported secondary outcomes for children.

    Child as an adult

    No studies reported secondary outcomes for children as adults.

    Health services

    No studies reported secondary outcomes relating to health services. 

    3. Betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate

    Two arms of one small three‐arm trial, including 69 women and 69 infants (all mothers had singleton pregnancies) compared betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate (Subtil 2003).

    Primary outcomes
    Women

    The study reported no primary outcomes for women.

    Fetus/neonate

    We assessed the effect estimates for all infant primary outcomes to be very low certainty due to risk of bias and imprecision.

    Any known death after randomisation (i.e. fetal, neonatal, child, child as adult)

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between these two preparations of betamethasone in the risk of any known death since randomisation (all deaths reported by this study were neonatal, and babies were not followed up longer term; RR 0.32, 95% CI 0.01 to 7.69; 1 trial, 69 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 3.1; summary of findings Table 5).

    Respiratory distress syndrome

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between these two preparations of betamethasone in the risk of RDS (RR 0.19, 95% CI 0.01 to 3.91; 1 trial, 69 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 3.2; summary of findings Table 5).

    Intraventricular haemorrhage

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between these two preparations of betamethasone in the risk of IVH (RR 0.32, 95% CI 0.01 to 7.69; 1 trial, 69 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 3.3; summary of findings Table 5).

    Child

    Neurodevelopmental disability

    This trial followed up four children in the betamethasone phosphate group (who had been admitted to NICU as babies) to 18 months, and reported that none of those four children had a neurodevelopmental disability at 18 months. The trial did not follow up any infants in the betamethasone acetate plus phosphate group (because no babies in that group were admitted to NICU as babies), therefore we could not report an effect estimate for this outcome. No other outcomes relating to longer term follow‐up were reported. 

    Unreported outcomes

    The study did not report death.

    Child as an adult

    The study reported no primary outcomes for children as adults.

    Secondary outcomes
    Women

    The study reported no secondary outcomes for women.

    Fetus/neonate

    Birthweight

    We are uncertain if there are any difference  between infants exposed to betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate for  birthweight (MD –0.10 kg, 95% CI –0.44 to 0.24; 1 trial, 69 infants; Analysis 3.4).

    Low birthweight

    We are uncertain if there are any difference between infants exposed to betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate for low birthweight (RR 1.21, 95% CI 0.86 to 1.72; 1 trial, 69 infants; Analysis 3.5).

    Admission to neonatal intensive care unit

    We are uncertain if there are any difference between infants exposed to betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate for admission to NICU (RR 0.11, 95% CI 0.01 to 1.93; 1 trial, 69 infants; Analysis 3.6). No infants from the betamethasone acetate plus phosphate group were admitted to NICU compared with four in the betamethasone phosphate group, all four due to respiratory distress.

    Bronchopulmonary dysplasia

    There were no instances of bronchopulmonary dysplasia (Analysis 3.7).

    Periventricular leukomalacia

    There were no instances of periventricular leukomalacia (Analysis 3.8).

    Biophysical parameters

    The study measured a range of fetal heart rate indicators but only reported them in graphical form. The trial authors reported that none of the indicators showed significant differences between the different betamethasone formulations.

    Unreported outcomes

    The study did not report fetal death, neonatal death (up to 28 days after birth), Apgar score less than 7 at five minutes, interval between trial entry and birth, mean length at birth, mean head circumference at birth, mean skin fold thickness at birth, small‐for‐gestational age, mean placental weight, neonatal blood pressure, need for inotropic support (days), need for mechanical ventilation/continuous positive airways pressure, mean duration of mechanical ventilation/continuous positive airways pressure (days), air leak syndrome, need for oxygen supplementation, duration of oxygen supplementation (days), surfactant use, severity of RDS, chronic lung disease (need for continuous supplemental oxygen at 28 days' postnatal age or 36 weeks' postmenstrual age, whichever was later), severe IVH, systemic infection in first 48 hours of life (neonatal sepsis), proven infection while in the NICU, necrotising enterocolitis, retinopathy of prematurity, patent ductus arteriosus or HPA axis function.

    Child

    The study reported no secondary outcomes for children.

    Child as an adult

    The study reported no secondary outcomes for children as adults.

    Health services

    The study reported no secondary outcomes relating to health services. 

    4. Betamethasone dosing interval: 12 hourly versus 24 hourly

    One trial involving 228 women and 260 infants compared betamethasone 12 hourly versus 24 hourly, with women randomised on a 2:1 ratio (and stratified into four groups by gestational age at trial entry) (Khandelwal 2012). 

    Primary outcomes
    Women

    The study reported no primary outcomes for women.

    Fetus/neonate

    Any known death after randomisation

    For any known death after randomisation, this trial reported perinatal deaths only, and did not follow up children longer term. Given the very low‐certainty evidence, it is unclear whether the betamethasone dosing interval made a difference to this outcome (RR 0.93, 95% CI 0.46 to 1.87; 1 trial, 255 infants; Analysis 4.1; summary of findings Table 6). We note that there was a much higher rate of perinatal death in both groups in this trial than for other studies included  in this review (compare summary of findings Table 2; summary of findings Table 4; summary of findings Table 5; summary of findings Table 6). The authors did not comment on the rate of perinatal death in the study.

    Respiratory distress syndrome

    We are uncertain whether the betamethasone dosing interval makes a difference to the risk of RDS (RR 0.95, 95% CI 0.67 to 1.36, 1 trial, 253 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 4.2; summary of findings Table 6).

    Intraventricular haemorrhage

    We are uncertain whether the betamethasone dosing interval makes a difference to the risk of IVH (RR 1.40, 95% CI 0.73 to 2.70; 1 trial, 253 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 4.3; summary of findings Table 6).

    Child

    The study reported no primary outcomes for children.

    Child as an adult

    The study reported no primary outcomes for children as adults.

    Secondary outcomes
    Women

    Maternal fever

    We are uncertain whether there is a difference between groups in the risk of maternal fever (defined as greater than 100.4 °F) (RR 0.71, 95% CI 0.25 to 2.02; 1 trial, 213 women; Analysis 4.4).

    The study did not report admission to intensive care unit, adverse effects of therapy, glucose intolerance or hypertension.

    Fetus/neonate

    Birthweight

    There may be little or no difference between groups for mean birthweight (MD 0.08 kg, 95% CI –0.15 to 0.31; 1 trial, 255 infants; Analysis 4.5).

    Small‐for‐gestational age

    The evidence is unclear whether there is a difference in risk of the baby being small‐for‐gestational age (RR 0.61, 95% CI 0.36 to 1.05; 1 trial, 255 infants; Analysis 4.6).

    Admission to neonatal intensive care unit

    It is possible that there may be a lower risk of admission to NICU with 12‐hourly regimen compared with the 24‐hourly regimen (RR 0.83, 95% CI 0.74 to 0.93; 1 trial, 253 infants; Analysis 4.7).

    Chronic lung disease

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between the dosing regimens for chronic lung disease (RR 0.77, 95% CI 0.48 to 1.24; 1 trial, 253 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 4.8; summary of findings Table 6).

    Neonatal sepsis

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between the dosing regimens for neonatal sepsis (RR 1.15, CI 0.47 to 2.81; 1 trial, 253 infants; Analysis 4.9).

    Proven infection while in the neonatal intensive care unit

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between the dosing regimens for neonatal antibiotic use of more than five days (RR 0.94, 95% CI 0.61 to 1.46; 1 trial, 253 infants; Analysis 4.10).

    Necrotising enterocolitis

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between the dosing regimens for necrotising enterocolitis (RR 9.08, 95% CI 0.54 to 153.08; 1 trial, 253 infants; very low‐certainty evidence; Analysis 4.11; summary of findings Table 6). No infants in the 24‐hour group developed necrotising enterocolitis while 10 infants in the 12‐hour group developed this outcome.

    Retinopathy of prematurity

    We are uncertain whether there are differences between the dosing regimens for retinopathy of prematurity (RR 1.01, 95% CI 0.53 to 1.95; 1 trial, 253 infants; Analysis 4.12).

    Unreported outcomes

    The study did not report fetal death, neonatal death (up to 28 days after birth), Apgar score less than 7 at five minutes, interval between trial entry and birth, low birthweight, mean length at birth, mean head circumference at birth, mean skin fold thickness at birth, mean placental weight, neonatal blood pressure, need for inotropic support (days), need for mechanical ventilation/continuous positive airways pressure, mean duration of mechanical ventilation/continuous positive airways pressure (days), air leak syndrome, need for oxygen supplementation, duration of oxygen supplementation (days), surfactant use, severity of RDS, bronchopulmonary dysplasia (variously defined), severe IVH, periventricular leukomalacia, patent ductus arteriosus, HPA axis function or biophysical parameters.

    Child

    The study reported no secondary outcomes for children.

    Child as an adult

    The study reported no secondary outcomes for children as adults.

    Health services

    In this trial, women who received the 12‐hour dosing interval of betamethasone had a slightly shorter mean postpartum maternal length of stay than women who received the 24‐hour dosing interval (MD –0.73 days, 95% CI –1.28 to –0.18; 1 trial, 215 women; Analysis 4.13).

    Discussion

    Summary of main results

    This update includes 11 trials (2494 women and 2762 infants). We implemented the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth's Trustworthiness Screening Tool for the first time, removing data from two previously included trials as a result (Chen 2005 (TST); Danesh 2012 (TST)), and adding one large new trial (the A*STEROID trial, Crowther 2019), adding 937 women and 1101 infants overall since the previous update. For the comparison of dexamethasone versus betamethasone, this affected most previously included outcomes while adding information on some maternal outcomes and longer‐term outcomes for the child. There was no new evidence on any other comparisons. 

    Dexamethasone versus betamethasone

    Nine trials including 2096 women and 2319 infants compared dexamethasone versus betamethasone, and while the route (intramuscular) and total dose in the course given was consistent, the dose, number of doses, dosing interval and drug preparation varied (see Table 1). While we did not identify clear evidence of a difference between the two drugs, there is some uncertainty around potential important differences for several maternal, infant and child outcomes. Crowther 2019 found no conclusive evidence of a difference between the two drugs for chorioamnionitis. Although the point estimate suggested a risk reduction with dexamethasone, the 95% CIs included one (moderate‐certainty evidence). No included studies reported our other primary outcomes for the mother (death and puerperal sepsis). In terms of our main secondary outcomes, the rate of maternal adverse effects was lower with dexamethasone, but again we did not find conclusive evidence that there is a true difference between drugs (moderate‐certainty evidence). The only other secondary outcome reported for the mother was postnatal fever requiring antibiotics, and the choice of drug probably makes little or no difference to the risk of this outcome.

    For primary outcomes for the baby, the point estimate suggests that the choice of drug probably makes little or no difference to the risk of any death after randomisation; however, the 95% CI included the possibility for both appreciable benefit and appreciable harm with dexamethasone (moderate‐certainty evidence), while there is probably little or no difference to the risk of RDS (high‐certainty evidence). There may be little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk of IVH; however, there was substantial unexplained statistical heterogeneity in the effect estimate. In terms of our main secondary outcomes for the baby, there may little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for chronic lung disease, but the analysis for necrotising enterocolitis was underpowered to identify any differences. For other secondary outcomes, analyses for some less common neonatal morbidity outcomes were underpowered to detect the true effect (e.g. Apgar score less than 7 at five minutes, bronchopulmonary dysplasia, neonatal sepsis, neonatal infection in the first 48 hours, severe IVH, retinopathy of prematurity), and there was also substantial unexplained statistical heterogeneity in the effect estimates for some  neonatal morbidity outcomes (bronchopulmonary dysplasia, retinopathy of prematurity). 

    Although extensively reported in several of the older included trials (Magee 1997; Mushkat 2001 Rotmensch 1999; Senat 1998; Subtil 2003), and also included in a small substudy of  Crowther 2019, the clinical significance of any differences in biophysical parameters such as fetal heart rate and respiratory rate was not clear (Rotmensch 1999). Crowther 2019 found no differences between groups for any biophysical parameters, fetal or maternal Doppler studies, or CTG, although we note that this substudy included only a small subset of the total women randomised (and is accordingly described by the authors as a prospective cohort study). Some of the older trials found indications of a lower heart rate at day two, a longer duration of breathing time at day two, and more fetal movements detected via ultrasound for the dexamethasone group. Some authors suggest that the influence of antenatal corticosteroids on parameters such as fetal heart rate is not clinically important, being a transient physiological response (Magee 1997; Rotmensch 1999; Subtil 2003).

    Only one study attempted to follow up all children longer term, at two years of age adjusted for prematurity, and this study overwhelmingly drove the findings that there is probably little or no difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone in the risk of neurodevelopmental disability. The findings from this study found no clear differences to our other main longer‐term outcomes (visual impairment, hearing impairment, motor developmental delay, intellectual impairment), or to other secondary outcomes at the same time point (mean weight, height, head circumference, systolic or diastolic blood pressure, or most other developmental outcomes). However, the effect estimate for cerebral palsy is compatible with both an important increase in risk with dexamethasone, and no difference between interventions for this outcome (low‐certainty evidence).

    Comparisons of different regimens and preparations of dexamethasone or betamethasone

    We found three studies that each included a comparison of a different regimen or preparation of either dexamethasone or betamethasone (dexamethasone 32 mg orally versus dexamethasone 24 mg intramuscularly; betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate; 12‐hourly betamethasone versus 24‐hourly betamethasone). While it is noteworthy that the first of these studies was stopped early due to safety concerns relating to oral dexamethasone, we were limited in our ability to draw conclusions from any of these studies due to their small sample size, concerns about risk of bias and limited number of outcomes reported. 

    Overall completeness and applicability of evidence

    All trials were conducted in high‐income countries, which may limit the wider applicability of this review's findings.

    The gestational age at trial entry varied from 23 to 35 weeks of gestation. While women in all trials were at increased risk of preterm birth or had a medical indication for preterm birth, assessment of risk was not described in a number of studies.

    For comparison of dexamethasone versus betamethasone, the included studies did not report most of our outcomes for the mother, so it is impossible to provide a complete picture of the effect of choice of drug on the woman's health and well‐being.

    There are important uncertainties around some severe neonatal morbidities and one longer‐term developmental outcome (including some outcomes that we judged to be most important, namely IVH, necrotising enterocolitis and cerebral palsy), in large part due to rarity and associated imprecision or heterogeneity between trials, or both. Our analyses were further limited as not all studies reported these neonatal outcomes. Assessment of longer‐term outcomes is crucial to any review of the effectiveness and safety of antenatal corticosteroids for women and babies. Only one study attempted to follow up all infants longer term, but there was attrition at two‐year follow‐up. No studies provided data on longer‐term follow‐up. 

    Most of the data available focused on the type of corticosteroid used, with nine studies comparing the two most commonly used corticosteroids, dexamethasone and betamethasone (with some variation in frequency and timing of administration). Considering the full scope of this review, our ability to reach comprehensive conclusions was limited by the small number of comparisons of different antenatal corticosteroid regimens. Evidence about optimal doses, timing, frequency of administration and preparation of specific antenatal corticosteroids was sparse, with three small trials contributing data to three separate comparisons. 

    Quality of the evidence

    We included 11 trials (involving 2494 women and 2762 infants) in this review update, including one large trial that was at minimal risk of bias overall (Crowther 2019), eight trials that we found to be at moderate risk of bias, and two further trials that we deemed to be at more serious risk of bias (Mulder 1997; Mushkat 2001). Our most common risk of bias concerns related to a lack of blinding of participants and personnel, missing outcome data and uncertainty about selective reporting bias. More serious worries related to selection bias (in Mulder 1997 the method of sequence generation was unclear, and Mushkat 2001 was quasi‐randomised).

    Our GRADE assessments factored in these risk of bias concerns, as well as downgrades for imprecision, due to small sample size, few events or wide CIs. 

    Potential biases in the review process

    One review authors was also an author on the A*STEROID trial (Crowther 2019). Two other review authors performed data extraction and risk of bias assessments for that trial. 

    To improve the reliability of the results reported in this review, and in line with current Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth group policy, we implemented the Cochrane Pregnancy and Childbirth's Trustworthiness Screening Tool for the first time in this review. We acknowledge that while the process involved was rigorous and systematic, it also involved a degree of subjective judgement, and it is possible that a different author team would have made different decisions about inclusion of studies and data. In this respect, the TST is similar to the assessment of risk of bias or the GRADE process; in all cases, we sought to be consistent and transparent, and thoroughly document our decisions and underlying rationale. 

    Agreements and disagreements with other studies or reviews

    One Cochrane Review comparing antenatal corticosteroids for fetal lung maturation versus placebo conducted subgroup analyses by type of corticosteroid therapy (McGoldrick 2020). While for most outcomes these analyses did not support the hypothesis that there is a difference between drugs, there may be some indication of a difference between dexamethasone and betamethasone for RDS, moderate/severe RDS and chorioamnionitis. For chorioamnionitis, the subgroup analyses suggested that the risk may be reduced with betamethasone but may be increased with dexamethasone, while conversely our results suggest there may be a reduction in risk with dexamethasone. However, for all three outcomes, the authors noted the observed differences may be due to chance.

    One recent systematic review and network meta‐analysis specifically investigated dexamethasone versus betamethasone for preterm birth (Ciapponi 2021). The authors concluded that their review identified no important differences between dexamethasone and betamethasone for most key neonatal and neurodevelopmental outcomes; however, they observed that there may be clinically important differences between these drugs for chorioamnionitis, fetal death, endometritis or puerperal sepsis, and RDS. Due to these uncertainties, which do not consistently align towards one drug or the other, the authors argued that further research is warranted. Although our review did not identify the same concerns relating to fetal death or RDS, we also found important uncertainties around some critical outcomes, with inconclusive evidence that may favour either dexamethasone (for chorioamnionitis, maternal adverse effects of therapy) or betamethasone (for cerebral palsy), and missing evidence on key outcomes including puerperal sepsis. 

    One recent review article raised concerns about the use of betamethasone acetate in antenatal corticosteroid therapy, and the size of the dose of antenatal corticosteroid (dexamethasone or betamethasone) that women receive (Jobe 2021). We found the evidence was inadequate to further understanding of these concerns. Most studies included in our review that compared dexamethasone versus betamethasone administered a betamethasone preparation that included betamethasone acetate, and all women in both groups received a similar total dose (22.8 mg to 24 mg). We only found one small three‐arm study that included a comparison of different betamethasone preparations (betamethasone acetate plus phosphate versus betamethasone phosphate), but it provided only very low‐certainty evidence for all reported outcomes (Subtil 2003).

    *The risk in the intervention group (and its 95% confidence interval) is based on the assumed risk in the comparison group and the relative effect of the intervention (and its 95% CI).

    CI: confidence interval; RCT: randomised controlled trial; RR: risk ratio.

    GRADE Working Group grades of evidence
    High certainty: we are very confident that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect.
    Moderate certainty: we are moderately confident in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect, but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.
    Low certainty: our confidence in the effect estimate is limited: the true effect may be substantially different from the estimate of the effect.
    Very low certainty: we have very little confidence in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be substantially different from the estimate of effect.

    aDowngraded one level for serious imprecision: 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit while also crossing line of no effect. The single study that provided most or all of the data for this outcome was large and conducted across 14 maternity hospitals in two countries. It was also free of risk of bias concerns. Therefore, although data were provided by a single study, we did not downgrade the effect estimate for this outcome on that basis.

    *The risk in the intervention group (and its 95% confidence interval) is based on the assumed risk in the comparison group and the relative effect of the intervention (and its 95% CI).

    CI: confidence interval; RCT: randomised controlled trial; RR: risk ratio.

    GRADE Working Group grades of evidence
    High certainty: we are very confident that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect.
    Moderate certainty: we are moderately confident in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect, but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.
    Low certainty: our confidence in the effect estimate is limited: the true effect may be substantially different from the estimate of the effect.
    Very low certainty: we have very little confidence in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be substantially different from the estimate of effect.

    aDowngraded one level for serious imprecision: 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm.
    bAlthough some studies contributing to the pooled effect estimate had limitations in study design, a sensitivity analysis limited only to studies free of concerns relating to risk of bias (this included only Crowther 2019, a large, multicentre study) revealed that inclusion of these studies did not significantly change the effect estimate; therefore, we have not downgraded for risk of bias.
    cDowngraded one level for serious imprecision: 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm. Also downgraded one level for serious risk of bias and substantial unexplained statistical heterogeneity: trials contributing almost half the weight to this analysis were at risk of bias, and their inclusion qualitatively impacted the effect estimate. We also had concerns about unexplained statistical heterogeneity (I² = 62%). Although there were insufficient trials to investigate this heterogeneity through prespecified subgroup analyses, it is possible that this heterogeneity was related to risk of bias; therefore, we downgraded once only. We note that Elimian 2007 reported very different results from other trials, and when trial was excluded, there was no heterogeneity in the effect estimate; this trial was at risk of bias for missing outcome data, as it did not report this outcome for all babies (100/181 with betamethasone versus 105/178 with dexamethasone) and it is not explicit in the trial report why this is so. The effect estimate if Elimian 2007 is excluded is RR 1.06, 95% CI 0.66 to 1.68.
    dDowngraded one level for serious imprecision: 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm. The single study that provided most or all of the data for this outcome was large and conducted across 14 maternity hospitals in two countries. It was also free of risk of bias concerns. Therefore, although data were provided by a single study, we did not downgrade the effect estimate further for this outcome.
    eDowngraded two levels for very serious imprecision: few events; 95% CIs included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm.

    *The risk in the intervention group (and its 95% confidence interval) is based on the assumed risk in the comparison group and the relative effect of the intervention (and its 95% CI).

    CI: confidence interval; RCT: randomised controlled trial; RR: risk ratio.

    GRADE Working Group grades of evidence
    High certainty: we are very confident that the true effect lies close to that of the estimate of the effect.
    Moderate certainty: we are moderately confident in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be close to the estimate of the effect, but there is a possibility that it is substantially different.
    Low certainty: our confidence in the effect estimate is limited: the true effect may be substantially different from the estimate of the effect.
    Very low certainty: we have very little confidence in the effect estimate: the true effect is likely to be substantially different from the estimate of effect.

    aDowngraded one level for serious limitations in study design: for the study contributing most or all of the weight to this effect estimate, there was loss to follow‐up greater than 20% in each group. Although this attrition is understandable for longer‐term outcomes, we do not know what happened many babies, and it is possible that the effect could differ substantively based on their outcomes.
    bDowngraded two levels for very serious imprecision and risk of attrition bias: few events and  95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm; there was approximately 20% loss to follow‐up in each group, which could have a substantial impact on the effect estimate. The single study that provided most or all of the data for this outcome was large and conducted across 14 maternity hospitals in two countries. Therefore, although data were provided by a single study, we did not downgrade the effect estimate for this outcome on that basis. 
    cDowngraded one level for serious imprecision and risk of attrition bias: 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm; there was approximately 20% loss to follow‐up in each group, which could have a substantial impact on the effect estimate. The single study that provided most or all of the data for this outcome was large and conducted across 14 maternity hospitals in two countries. Therefore, although data were provided by a single study, we did not downgrade the effect estimate for this outcome on that basis.
    dDowngraded one level for serious imprecision and risk of attrition bias: 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit while also crossing line of no effect; there was approximately 23% loss to follow‐up in each group, which could have a substantial impact on the effect estimate. The single study that provided most or all of the data for this outcome was large and conducted across 14 maternity hospitals in two countries. Therefore, although data were provided by a single study, we did not downgrade the effect estimate for this outcome on that basis.
    eDowngraded two levels for very serious imprecision and risk of attrition bias: few events; 95% confidence intervals included appreciable harm and crosses line of no effect; there was approximately 20% loss to follow‐up in each group, which could have a substantial impact on the effect estimate. The single study that provided most or all of the data for this outcome was large and conducted across 14 maternity hospitals in two countries. Therefore, although data were provided by a single study, we did not downgrade the effect estimate for this outcome on that basis.

    aDowngraded one level for serious risk of bias: single study contributing data for this outcome was at risk of bias due to lack of blinding of participants and personnel, and we also had concerns about baseline imbalances and missing outcome data. We also downgraded two levels for very serious imprecision: small sample size; 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm.
    bDowngraded one level for serious risk of bias: single study contributing data for this outcome was at risk of bias due to lack of blinding of participants and personnel, and we also had concerns about baseline imbalances and missing outcome data. We also downgraded two levels for very serious imprecision: few events, small sample size; 95% confidence intervals included appreciable benefit and appreciable harm.
